page.title: 01The lowlands of Gruinard
page.content: The landscape ranges from rocky mountains to sea coasts. The natural herbage is heather and rough grasses, with a few wild rowan and birch. There are also some coniferous forestry plantations. The trees are mainly round the coast. The earth is shallow and stoney, with peat bogs in valleys. Only a small part is cultivated. There is a farm with fields for grazing and silage & a garden attached to Gruinard House. Sheep & cattle are kept on the low ground in winter, & grazed on the hill ground in summer. There are many red deer, & a small herd of wild goats. Also otters, wild cats, pine martins, seals & foxes. less common birds here include buzzards, sparrow hawks, eagles. The area is part of a 28000 acre estate. There are 8 houses, 4 used as holiday houses 7 people live here permanently, 3 work for estate.
